name: Bells Beach
description: Bells Beach is a world-renowned right-hand point break in Victoria, Australia, famous for its long, powerful walls and natural amphitheater setting. It is home to the Rip Curl Pro, the world's longest-running professional surfing competition.

name: Snapper Rocks
description: Snapper Rocks is a world-famous right-hand sand point break on the Gold Coast of Australia. It is the starting point of the 'Superbank,' a man-made phenomenon that can produce incredibly long, fast, and barreling waves connecting through Rainbow Bay and Greenmount on the best swells.

name: Kirra
description: Kirra is a legendary right-hand point break on the Gold Coast, Queensland, renowned for its incredibly long, fast, and hollow barrels that break over a sand bottom. When conditions align, it's considered one of the best sand-bottomed point breaks in the world.

name: Burleigh Heads
description: Burleigh Heads is a world-class right-hand point break on Australia's Gold Coast, renowned for its long, fast, and hollow barrels that peel perfectly along a sandy bottom fringed by basalt boulders. It offers multiple sections, from the expert-only barrels at 'The Cove' to more forgiving walls further down the point.

name: Duranbah
description: Duranbah, often called D-bah, is a world-class beach break located on the border of New South Wales and Queensland. Known for its powerful, consistent A-frame peaks, it offers high-performance lefts and rights, with the Tweed River breakwall providing protection from southerly winds.

name: Greenmount
description: Greenmount is a classic right-hand point break on Australia's Gold Coast, forming the beginning of the legendary Superbank. It's known for its long, mellow, and user-friendly waves, making it a favorite for longboarders and intermediate surfers.

name: The Superbank
description: The Superbank is a world-famous, man-made right-hand sand point break on the Gold Coast of Australia. On a classic swell, it connects several breaks from Snapper Rocks to Kirra, offering incredibly long, fast, and barreling rides.

name: Noosa Heads
description: Noosa Heads is a series of world-class right-hand sand-bottom point breaks on Queensland's Sunshine Coast. Famous for its exceptionally long, peeling, and user-friendly waves, it is a longboarder's paradise that works best on cyclone swells.

name: North Narrabeen
description: North Narrabeen is a world-class beach break on Sydney's Northern Beaches, renowned for its hollow, powerful left-hand barrels that break over shifting sandbanks at the entrance to Narrabeen Lagoon. It is a designated National Surfing Reserve and a regular stop on professional surfing tours.

name: Manly Beach
description: Manly Beach is a famous and bustling beach break located in Sydney's Northern Beaches, offering a variety of peaks suitable for different skill levels. It's known for its consistent waves and vibrant beach culture, making it a popular spot for both locals and tourists.

name: Bondi Beach
description: Bondi Beach is one of Australia's most iconic city beaches, located in Sydney, New South Wales. It is a popular, often crowded beach break that offers a variety of sand-bottomed peaks suitable for all skill levels, from beginners to advanced surfers.

name: Maroubra
description: Maroubra is a large and consistent beach break located in Sydney's eastern suburbs. As a National Surfing Reserve, it's known for its powerful waves that offer multiple peaks working on various swells, catering to a wide range of skill levels.

name: Cronulla Point
description: Cronulla Point is a legendary and powerful right-hand reef break located in Sydney's south. Known for its heavy barrels and challenging sections, it breaks over a shallow rock shelf and is best suited for experienced surfers.

name: Angourie
description: Angourie is a legendary right-hand point break in New South Wales, Australia, renowned for its long, hollow, and fast-breaking waves over a rock bottom. Declared the first National Surfing Reserve in NSW, it's a hallowed ground for experienced surfers.

name: Lennox Head
description: Lennox Head is a legendary right-hand point break in New South Wales, Australia, renowned for its long, fast, and often hollow waves that break over a boulder-strewn bottom. It's a high-performance wave that attracts experienced surfers from around the globe.

name: Byron Bay - The Pass
description: The Pass is an iconic, super-long right-hand sand point break located in Byron Bay, Australia. Famous for its incredibly long rides and beautiful setting, it is one of the most popular and crowded surf spots in the country, catering to longboarders and shortboarders alike.

name: Crescent Head
description: Crescent Head is a legendary right-hand point break on the mid-north coast of New South Wales, celebrated for its incredibly long and user-friendly rides. It is considered one of the world's classic longboarding waves, peeling perfectly for hundreds of meters.
ideal_tide: All tides, best on mid to low

name: Margaret River Main Break
description: Margaret River Main Break, also known as Surfers Point, is a world-class, heavy reef break in Western Australia. It is renowned for its consistency and powerful right and left-handers that can hold significant swell, making it a key stop on the World Surf League Championship Tour.

name: The Box
description: The Box is an infamous and highly dangerous right-hand slab located in Margaret River. It is known for its incredibly thick, square, and fast-barreling waves that break over an extremely shallow and sharp reef, making it a spot for expert surfers only.

name: Yallingup
description: Yallingup is a classic and versatile reef break in Western Australia's Margaret River region, known for its consistency and quality waves. The main peak offers a long, workable right-hander and a shorter, more intense left, making it a popular and reliable spot.

name: Trigg Beach
description: Trigg Beach is one of Perth's most consistent and popular surf spots, featuring a main reef break at Trigg Point and numerous sandbars along the beach. Its reliability and variety of peaks make it a central hub for the local surfing community in Western Australia.

name: Scarborough Beach
description: Scarborough Beach is a popular and consistent urban beach break in Perth, Western Australia. It features numerous sandbar peaks along a long stretch of white sand, offering punchy left and right-hand waves that work on a variety of swells.

name: Strickland Bay, Rottnest Island
description: Strickland Bay is a highly consistent and powerful A-frame reef break on the southwest side of Rottnest Island. Considered one of the best waves in the Perth region, it offers a hollow left and a longer, walling right over a shallow reef, attracting experienced surfers.

name: Torquay Surf Beach
description: Torquay Surf Beach, often called Cosy Corner, is a protected and gentle beach break located in the heart of Australia's surf capital. Its forgiving, sandy bottom and smaller, consistent waves make it an ideal and popular location for beginner surfers and surf schools.

name: Jan Juc
description: Jan Juc is a popular and powerful beach break located adjacent to the world-famous Bells Beach. It offers various sand-bottomed peaks, providing both lefts and rights that are often more forgiving than its neighboring reef. The waves can be fun and manageable for intermediates but become heavy and challenging in a larger swell.

name: Winkipop
description: Winkipop is a fast, hollow right-hand point break located just north of the more famous Bells Beach. Often considered more high-performance than its neighbor, it offers racy walls and barrel sections, making it a favorite among advanced surfers.

name: Johanna Beach
description: Johanna Beach is a powerful and often heavy beach break on Victoria's Great Ocean Road. Known as a swell magnet, it features shifting sandbanks that produce punchy peaks and is a reliable backup location for the Rip Curl Pro.

name: Portsea
description: Portsea Back Beach is a powerful and often heavy beach break on the Mornington Peninsula. Known for its strong rips and shifty sandbanks, it offers punchy A-frame peaks best suited for experienced surfers.

name: Gunnamatta
description: Gunnamatta is a powerful and consistent beach break on the Mornington Peninsula, known for its shifting sandbanks that produce punchy A-frame peaks. Exposed to the full force of the Southern Ocean, it's a swell magnet notorious for strong rips and is best suited for experienced surfers.

name: Phillip Island
description: Phillip Island is a wave-rich region with numerous breaks. A popular sheltered option is Cat Bay, a western-facing spot that provides fun, peeling left-handers over a reef bottom, working best when southerly winds make other beaches unsurfable.

name: Woolamai
description: Woolamai is a powerful and exposed beach break on Phillip Island, known for its consistent, heavy waves and strong rips. As one of Victoria's biggest swell magnets, it offers numerous shifting sand-bar peaks with both lefts and rights.

name: Cactus Beach
description: Cactus Beach is a legendary and remote collection of powerful reef breaks in South Australia, revered for its pristine beauty and hollow, world-class waves. Situated in a shark-heavy area, it offers several A-frame peaks and is suitable only for experienced surfers.

name: Pennington Bay
description: Pennington Bay is a stunning and powerful beach break on the south coast of Kangaroo Island, exposed to consistent Southern Ocean swells. It offers multiple punchy peaks over sand but is known for strong rips, making it a spot for experienced surfers.

name: Vivonne Bay
description: Vivonne Bay is a picturesque beach break on Kangaroo Island, known for its clear turquoise water and consistent, punchy waves. This exposed Southern Ocean spot breaks over a sand bottom and is best suited for intermediate surfers.

name: Parsons Beach
description: Parsons Beach is a powerful and consistent beach break on South Australia's Fleurieu Peninsula, known for its punchy A-frame peaks that offer both lefts and rights. Its exposure to Southern Ocean swells and strong rips make it a go-to spot for experienced surfers.

name: Waitpinga Beach
description: Waitpinga Beach is a powerful and often heavy beach break on the Fleurieu Peninsula, exposed to the full force of the Southern Ocean. Known for its strong rips and challenging conditions, it features shifting sandbanks that produce punchy waves best suited for experienced surfers.

name: Middleton
description: Middleton is a popular and consistent beach break on South Australia's Fleurieu Peninsula, renowned for its gentle, rolling waves. It offers multiple peaks with both left and right-hand waves, making it an ideal and safe spot for beginners and longboarders.

name: Goolwa Beach
description: Goolwa Beach is a long, exposed sandy beach break in South Australia, offering consistent and accessible waves. It is a very popular location for surf schools and beginner surfers due to its typically mellow peaks breaking both left and right.

name: Southport
description: Southport, often referred to as The Spit, is a world-class beach break on the Gold Coast known for its powerful, dredging barrels. The quality of the wave is highly dependent on the shifting sandbanks, which can produce incredibly long, hollow right-handers during cyclone swells.

name: North Stradbroke Island
description: North Stradbroke Island, or 'Straddie', is a large sand island off the coast of Brisbane, renowned for its powerful beach breaks and a classic right-hand point break at Point Lookout. The island's exposed coastline picks up consistent swell, offering a variety of waves from hollow barrels to more user-friendly peelers.

name: Coolangatta (Superbank)
description: The Superbank is a world-famous, man-made, sand-bottomed right-hand point break on the Gold Coast. On classic cyclone swells, the wave can connect from Snapper Rocks through Rainbow Bay and Greenmount, offering incredibly long rides and multiple barrel sections.

name: Currumbin Alley
description: Currumbin Alley is a famous right-hand sand point break on Australia's Gold Coast, known for its long, peeling, and often gentle waves. Protected from southerly winds by Currumbin Rock, it's a popular spot for longboarders, beginners, and intermediate surfers, offering rides that can run for hundreds of meters.

name: Palm Beach (QLD)
description: Palm Beach is a long, exposed beach break on Queensland's Gold Coast, offering numerous shifting sandbanks that create various peaks. It is a consistent spot known for producing powerful and often hollow waves, particularly on a clean groundswell.

name: Moffat Beach
description: Moffat Beach is a classic right-hand point break located on Queensland's Sunshine Coast, renowned for its long, peeling waves ideal for longboarding. The wave breaks off the Moffat Headland, offering extended rides that can be fast and hollow in the right conditions.

name: Alexandra Headland
description: Alexandra Headland, affectionately known as 'Alex', is a classic right-hand point break on Queensland's Sunshine Coast. It offers long, user-friendly rides on a sand bottom, making it a popular and often crowded spot for a range of surfers.

name: Coolum Beach
description: Coolum Beach is a popular and consistent beach break on Queensland's Sunshine Coast, offering numerous sandbanks that produce fun left and right-handers. It is a versatile spot suitable for all skill levels, set against the iconic backdrop of Mount Coolum.

name: Sunshine Beach
description: Sunshine Beach is a long, exposed stretch of sand in Queensland, Australia, located just south of the Noosa Headland. It offers multiple peaks producing punchy, often hollow waves that work best in clean easterly groundswells.

name: Rainbow Bay
description: Rainbow Bay is a world-class right-hand sand-bottom point break on the Gold Coast, forming the beginning of the legendary Superbank. It's famous for producing incredibly long, peeling, and relatively user-friendly waves, though it is often extremely crowded.

name: Fingal Head
description: Fingal Head is a famous right-hand point break in northern New South Wales that offers fast, hollow, and often barrelling waves. The wave breaks off a rock shelf onto a sand bottom, creating a powerful wedge that attracts experienced surfers.

name: Cabarita Beach
description: Cabarita Beach is a versatile surf spot in northern New South Wales, featuring a high-quality right-hand point break off the headland. The area also offers several consistent beach break peaks, catering to a range of abilities and conditions.

name: Kingscliff
description: Kingscliff is a popular beach break in northern New South Wales offering multiple peaks along its sandy stretch. The most consistent waves are often found near the southern rock wall, which can produce fun, wedgy right-handers suitable for various skill levels.
